subsection.name: SchemaCrawler Lint
subsection.p: SchemaCrawler can analyze and lint your database to find potential issues. SchemaCrawler Lint can be run using the -infolevel=lint command-line option.

ul.li: Tables with incrementing column names, for example, a table with column names like contact1, contact2 and so on can indicate de-normalization. SchemaCrawler Lint will flag such tables with a lint message.
SchemaCrawler Lint will flag tables with just a single column with a lint message, since this could indicate a schema design smell.
SchemaCrawler Lint will flag tables with no indices with a lint message.
Tables where the default value is 'NULL' instead of NULL may indicate a error when creating a table. SchemaCrawler Lint will flag such tables with a lint message.
SchemaCrawler Lint will flag tables that have nullable columns in a unique index, with a lint message.
SchemaCrawler Lint will flag tables that have space in table or column names, or names that are reserved words in the ANSI SQL standard, with a lint message.

subsection.p: SchemaCrawler Lint also analyzes the database for weak associations. Weak associations are inferred associations between tables, similar to forign keys, even if there is no foreign key defined in the database between the tables. Ruby on Rails table schemes are supported, as well as other simple naming conventions. Table name prefixes are automatically detected. Weak associations are output in the graphs as a dotted line, and are also output in the text formats.
